overview: From 2025-06-23 to 2025-06-24, elizaos/eliza had 6 new PRs (5 merged), 2 new issues, and 13 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Deploy Eliza agents
topIssues.author: kamalbuilds
topIssues.body: What are the best ways to deploy custom eliza agents ?

topIssues.title: Issues setting up a project with desired provider and overall impression on the project
topIssues.author: urosognjenovic
topIssues.body:
I've been struggling to setup a project from scratch for over 10 days now so I've decided to open an issue here. 

I've tried using all the possible options:
- `eliza-starter` repo: First I tried with this one. After many unsuccessful attempts, I managed to get this up and running. However, the repo is now archived so I've decided to find another option. There should at least be a notice somewhere in the README explaining why the repo was archived as it is a bit confusing to come back to the repo you used yesterday and find it archived.
- `eliza` (this) repo. It references an old video from a few months ago that doesn't help very much as a lot of stuff has changed in the meantime. I tried following the README:
```
git clone https://github.com/elizaos/eliza.git
git checkout $(git describe --tags --abbrev=0)
cp .env.example .env
```
Then I set the `GOOGLE_GENERATIVE_AI_API_KEY` variable in `.env`. This is just my best guess for the variable name using the `eliza-starter` repo as there's no word on how to set up an agent using Gemini in the `.env` itself or in the docs.
Then I execute the rest of the commands:
```
bun install
bun run build
bun start
```
Here the agent starts and I navigate to http://localhost:3000 to try and text my agent. However, the error is `A context size of 8192 is too large for the available VRAM` as the model is started locally and my Gemini API key is ignored. 
- CLI tool: I create a new project by running `elizaos create my-agent` and choose the standard options, including the OpenAI LLM. Long story short, this one fails me as well because I can't in God's name figure out how to start the model using my desired provider or change it afterwards.

TL;DR There's a lack of synchronisation between the official documentation, this repo, and the CLI tool. It is very difficult to figure out where to look up the issues you have and find an answer to them.

This is just a fraction of the issues I've had along the way, all while just trying to set up a simple project.

topPRs.title: Added: Actions and ABIs for Alethea Plugin
topPRs.author: Samarthsinghal28
topPRs.body:
# Relates to

<!-- No specific issue linked -->

# Risks

**Medium** ‚Äî This PR introduces new plugin functionality and external interactions via ABIs and actions. It may affect downstream systems that rely on plugin behavior or Hive interactions.

# Background

## What does this PR do?

This pull request adds support for the Alethea Plugin by introducing:

- Basic ABIs required for interacting with external contracts or services.
- Core plugin actions needed for executing Alethea-related operations.
- Hive actions to support blockchain interactions related to the plugin's logic.

## What kind of change is this?

**Features** ‚Äì This is a non-breaking change that adds new functionality (Alethea plugin support via actions and ABIs).

# Documentation changes needed?

- [x] My changes require a change to the project documentation.
- [ ] My changes do not require a change to the project documentation.
- [x] I have updated the documentation accordingly.

# Testing

## Where should a reviewer start?

Begin by reviewing the new Alethea plugin files:

-  `packages/plugin-alethea/alethea`

## Detailed testing steps

- Use the UI or CLI (if available) to trigger Alethea actions.
- Verify the ABIs are correctly parsed and contract calls succeed.
- Confirm Hive actions log and respond as expected.

# Screenshots

- Already shared the test screenshots

topPRs.title: feat: add type-safe API client package
topPRs.author: wtfsayo
topPRs.body:
## Summary
- Added a new `@elizaos/api-client` package that provides a type-safe client for the ElizaOS server API
- Comprehensive TypeScript support with full type definitions for all API endpoints
- Clean, service-based architecture for easy consumption

## Features
### Service Coverage
- **Agents**: CRUD operations, lifecycle management, worlds, panels, and logs
- **Messaging**: Messages, channels, servers, DMs, and search functionality
- **Memory**: Agent memories, rooms, and world management
- **Audio**: Speech processing, text-to-speech, transcription
- **Media**: File uploads for agents and channels
- **Server**: Health checks, status monitoring, debug info
- **System**: Environment configuration

### Technical Implementation
- Type-safe request/response handling with proper error types
- Automatic FormData handling for file uploads
- Configurable base URL and API key authentication
- Comprehensive test coverage using bun:test
- Clean service separation for modularity
- Full TypeScript declaration files (.d.ts) generated

## Usage Example
```typescript
import { ElizaClient } from '@elizaos/api-client';

const client = ElizaClient.create({
  baseUrl: 'http://localhost:3000',
  apiKey: 'your-api-key', // optional
});

// List agents
const { agents } = await client.agents.listAgents();

// Send a message
const message = await client.messaging.postMessage(channelId, 'Hello\!');

// Upload media
const upload = await client.media.uploadAgentMedia(agentId, {
  file: myFile,
  filename: 'image.png',
});
```

## Test plan
- [x] Build succeeds without errors
- [x] All tests pass (11/11)
- [x] TypeScript compilation works correctly
- [x] Package integrates with monorepo structure
- [x] Type declaration files (.d.ts) are generated

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

- **New Features**
  - Introduced a type-safe API client package for ElizaOS, providing unified access to agents, messaging, memory, audio, media, server, and system APIs with comprehensive TypeScript type definitions.
  - Added a centralized client class aggregating all service domains for simplified usage.
  - Extensive public type definitions for all API domains are now available.

- **Bug Fixes**
  - Improved test reliability by updating test suites to use real localStorage and proper mocking utilities.
  - Updated test setups to use Happy DOM for more accurate DOM simulation in tests.

- **Documentation**
  - Added detailed README for the new API client package, including installation, usage examples, and error handling instructions.

- **Chores**
  - Added and updated configuration files for coverage, TypeScript, and build tooling across multiple packages.
  - Updated `.gitignore` files to prevent tracking of build artifacts and sensitive files.
  - Enhanced package metadata and module resolution for Bun compatibility.

- **Tests**
  - Added comprehensive test suites for all new API client service domains, ensuring robust coverage and error handling.
  - Refactored test files to improve isolation, reliability, and maintainability.

<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

topPRs.title: Add files via upload
topPRs.author: Dexploarer
topPRs.body:
üéØ Overview
This PR adds comprehensive configuration files for all major AI coding tools to ensure consistent development experience and enforce ElizaOS architectural patterns across the development community. üöÄ What's Changed
Added AI Tool Configurations for:

Windsurf IDE - Interactive workflows with quality gates Claude Code - Slash commands and project context
OpenAI Codex - Cloud and CLI configurations
GitHub Copilot - Repository instructions and prompt files Cursor IDE - Legacy and modern rule formats

üìÅ File Structure Added
.windsurf/                          # Windsurf IDE Configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ rules/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ elizaos-v2-main.md          # Core development principles
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ elizaos-architecture.md      # Component specifications
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ elizaos-testing.md          # Testing infrastructure
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ workflows/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ elizaos-development.yaml    # Main development workflow
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ elizaos-testing.yaml        # Testing automation
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ elizaos-component.yaml      # Component creation

.claude/                            # Claude Code Configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ commands/                       # Slash Commands
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dev.md                      # /project:dev
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test.md                     # /project:test
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bugfix.md                   # /project:bugfix
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ validate.md                 # /project:validate
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ review.md                   # /project:review
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ component.md                # /project:component
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ elizaos/                    # Namespaced Commands
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ action.md               # /project:elizaos:action
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ provider.md             # /project:elizaos:provider
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ evaluator.md            # /project:elizaos:evaluator
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ COMMANDS.md                     # Command reference

.github/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ copilot-instructions.md         # GitHub Copilot instructions
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ instructions/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions.md                  # Action development guidance
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ providers.md                # Provider development guidance
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ evaluators.md               # Evaluator development guidance
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ git-commit.md               # Commit message conventions
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ prompts/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ create-action.prompt.md     # Action creation workflow
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ run-tests.prompt.md         # Testing workflow

.cursor/                            # Modern Cursor IDE format
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rules/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.mdc                   # Core rules (always applied)
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ actions.mdc                 # Action development (context-aware)
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ testing.mdc                 # Testing rules (context-aware)

.cursorrules                        # Legacy Cursor IDE format
CLAUDE.md                           # Claude Code main configuration
docs/ai-development-setup.md        # Setup and usage guide
‚ú® Key Features
Universal Development Principles Enforcement
All AI tools now automatically enforce:

‚úÖ Flow - Always Plan First methodology
‚úÖ No Stubs or Incomplete Code rule
‚úÖ Test-Driven Development with elizaos test commands ‚úÖ Bun Runtime validation (never Node.js)
‚úÖ @elizaos/core dependency patterns (no circular dependencies) ‚úÖ Agent Perspective in abstractions (Channel‚ÜíRoom, Server‚ÜíWorld) ‚úÖ Component Specifications (Actions, Providers, Evaluators, Tasks, Services) ‚úÖ TypeScript Standards with comprehensive error handling

Tool-Specific Optimizations

Windsurf: Interactive workflows with /elizaos-development, /elizaos-testing
Claude Code: Slash commands like /project:dev, /project:elizaos:action
Codex: Project context via CLAUDE.md for both cloud and CLI versions
GitHub Copilot: Repository-wide instructions with component-specific guidance
Cursor: Context-aware rules that apply only when working on relevant files

üéÅ Benefits for ElizaOS Development Community
For Individual Developers

Consistent AI Assistance - Same architectural understanding across all tools Reduced Context Switching - No need to repeatedly explain ElizaOS patterns Quality Assurance - Automatic enforcement of development best practices Faster Onboarding - New developers get guided AI assistance immediately

For the Project

Code Quality - All AI-generated code follows ElizaOS standards Architecture Compliance - Prevents circular dependencies and pattern violations Testing Consistency - Enforces proper use of elizaos test commands Documentation - Self-documenting development practices through AI rules

For Teams

Standardization - Same AI behavior across all team members Knowledge Sharing - Codified best practices accessible to all AI tools Productivity - Streamlined development workflows with quality gates Collaboration - Consistent code generation patterns across contributors

üìñ Usage Instructions
Quick Setup (Choose Your Tool)
Windsurf IDE Users:

Rules automatically apply to Cascade AI
Use workflows: /elizaos-development, /elizaos-testing, /elizaos-component

Claude Code Users:

Slash commands available immediately: /project:dev, /project:test
Component creation: /project:elizaos:action, /project:elizaos:provider

GitHub Copilot Users:

Repository instructions automatically apply to all requests Prompt files available: @create-action, @run-tests

Cursor IDE Users:

Legacy: .cursorrules applies to all interactions
Modern: .cursor/rules/ provides context-aware guidance

OpenAI Codex Users:

Cloud: CLAUDE.md provides project context
CLI: See setup guide for global configuration

Detailed Setup
See docs/ai-development-setup.md for comprehensive setup instructions and advanced configuration options. üß™ Testing
These configurations have been tested with:

‚úÖ ElizaOS component development (Actions, Providers, Evaluators) ‚úÖ Bug fixing workflows with impact analysis
‚úÖ Test-driven development with elizaos test commands ‚úÖ Architecture validation (dependency checking, abstraction compliance) ‚úÖ Code review processes with ElizaOS standards

üîÑ Backwards Compatibility

No Breaking Changes - All files are additive configuration Optional Usage - Developers can choose which AI tools to configure Graceful Degradation - Works with existing development workflows Version Agnostic - Compatible with all current ElizaOS versions

üìö Documentation Updates

Added comprehensive setup guide: docs/ai-development-setup.md Updated development workflow documentation
Added AI tool configuration examples
Included troubleshooting guide for common AI tool issues

ü§ù Community Impact
This contribution enables the entire ElizaOS development community to:

Accelerate Development - AI tools that understand ElizaOS architecture Maintain Quality - Automatic enforcement of coding standards Share Knowledge - Codified development patterns accessible to all Scale Effectively - Consistent development practices across growing team

üîç Review Notes

All configurations follow ElizaOS architectural principles exactly Tool-specific optimizations leverage each AI platform's strengths Comprehensive testing ensures compatibility with existing workflows Documentation provides clear setup and usage instructions Community feedback incorporated throughout development

topPRs.title: Random Fixes
topPRs.author: Dexploarer
topPRs.body:
This pull request introduces a comprehensive AI configuration suite for ElizaOS, enhancing its development workflow with detailed guidelines, tool-specific setups, and a unified architecture for AI-assisted coding. The changes include new documentation, configuration files, and command templates to ensure consistency, quality, and efficiency across various AI tools.

### New Documentation and Guidelines:

* [`elizaos-ai-configs/CLAUDE.md`](diffhunk://#diff-0b2bd7f55ef35a132dbe6f12ba13f6783768e89e699927a3b5259f5cc0e43b48R1-R116): Added a detailed configuration guide for Claude, including development rules, architectural principles, testing strategies, and dependency management for ElizaOS projects.
* [`elizaos-ai-configs/README.md`](diffhunk://#diff-939063d40d6eb0b62e2b98d8e245c7c70bc5d3287bef06eb8085b56e009b9f9bR1-R310): Introduced an overarching README that explains the purpose, features, and benefits of the ElizaOS AI Configuration Suite, along with tool-specific highlights and setup instructions.
* [`elizaos-ai-configs/SETUP-GUIDE.md`](diffhunk://#diff-4219a7d2896279cb19f5654f72bdbcc639dc8bb891e7e7ac026ef42f35f63729R1-R68): Added a setup guide for configuring ElizaOS with various AI tools like Windsurf, Claude, OpenAI Codex, GitHub Copilot, and Cursor.

### Tool-Specific Command Templates:

* [`elizaos-ai-configs/claude code/commands/dev.md`](diffhunk://#diff-84628f9448f38b177f5f919081f3ecd85ac4261b80ff28844cd8a92dfcc379ceR1-R43): Added a template for the development workflow command `/project:dev`, enforcing the "Flow - Always Plan First" methodology and architectural validation steps.
* [`elizaos-ai-configs/claude code/commands/elizaos/action.md`](diffhunk://#diff-45650a92b8c1a39372c69e6e80c3a9e4b9d38695e2aef0306426b5bc392e9bd1R1-R47): Introduced a command template for creating Action components, with a focus on validation, handler implementation, and integration testing.
* [`elizaos-ai-configs/claude code/commands/test.md`](diffhunk://#diff-abdf0a8ddcee8f79b8761b2d97ee8dc5b1a2ee6d936b2c7eec66638fdb226327R1-R46): Added a testing command template `/project:test` to run component, end-to-end, and full test suites with pre-test validation steps.

These changes collectively establish a robust framework to streamline AI-assisted development for ElizaOS, ensuring high-quality, production-ready code across all supported tools.<!-- Use this template by filling in information and copying and pasting relevant items out of the HTML comments. -->

topPRs.title: refactor: centralize-directory-detection-logic
topPRs.author: yungalgo
topPRs.body:
## Description
  This PR centralizes scattered directory type detection logic throughout the CLI codebase into the `directory-detection` utility, eliminating code duplication and ensuring consistent behavior across all CLI commands. This had mostly been done the other week but there was some lingering stuff and artifacts so i did a comprehensive check here to ensure that everywhere in the code is using the same source of truth for directory detection and found a few files that were using other logic

  ### Problem Solved
  Previously, different parts of the CLI were implementing their own directory type detection logic:
  - Start command had its own project detection
  - E2E tests had separate context detection
  - Project utilities duplicated directory type checks
  - Build project had separate validation logic

  This led to:
  - **Code duplication** across multiple files
  - **Inconsistent behavior** when detecting project types
  - **Maintenance burden** when logic needed updates
  - **Potential bugs** from divergent implementations

  ### Solution
  Centralized all directory detection logic to use the existing `directory-detection` utility:

  #### Files Refactored:
  - **`start/index.ts`**: Now uses `detectDirectoryType()` instead of custom detection
  - **`e2e-tests.ts`**: Replaced context detection with centralized utility
  - **`project-utils.ts`**: Removed duplicate type detection logic
  - **`project.ts`**: Standardized on centralized directory detection
  - **`build-project.ts`**: Uses centralized validation instead of custom checks

  ### Benefits
  - ‚úÖ **Single source of truth** for directory detection logic
  - ‚úÖ **Consistent behavior** across all CLI commands
  - ‚úÖ **Reduced code duplication** (~50+ lines of duplicate logic removed)
  - ‚úÖ **Easier maintenance** - updates only needed in one place
  - ‚úÖ **Better testability** - directory detection logic centrally tested

  ### Testing
  - All existing functionality preserved
  - Behavior remains identical to users
  - Directory detection logic now properly centralized
